vague_description: A grocery store aims to optimize its remaining stock by devising two different fruit packages to maximize profits.
detailed_description: A grocery store wants to liquidate its stock of \var{ApplesStock} apples, \var{BananasStock} bananas, and \var{GrapesStock} grapes. Given past experience, the store knows that they can propose a banana-haters package with \var{ApplesBHPack} apples and \var{GrapesBHPack} grapes and that this package will bring a profit of \var{ProfitBHPack} euros. Similarly, they can prepare a combo package with \var{ApplesCombo} apples, \var{BananasCombo} bananas, and \var{GrapesCombo} grapes, yielding a profit of \var{ProfitCombo} euros. They know they can sell any quantity of these two packages within the availability of its stock. What quantity of each package, banana-haters packages and combo packages, should the store prepare to maximize net profit?
target_objective: Maximize the profit from selling banana-haters packages and combo packages
target_constraints: Number of banana-haters packages is non-negative
Number of combo packages is non-negative
The number of apples used in banana-haters and combo packages is less than or equal to ApplesStock
The number of bananas used in combo packages is less than or equal to BananasStock
The number of grapes used in banana-haters and combo packages is less than or equal to GrapesStock
target_parameters: Number of apples in a banana-haters package
Number of grapes in a banana-haters package
Number of apples in a combo package
Number of bananas in a combo package
Number of grapes in a combo package
